Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research (RAPID): Testing Intervention Strategies to Change the Outcome of Disease-caused Mass-mortality Events in a Declining Amphibian
Award.AbstractNarration: New diseases are emerging at an increasing rate, and in numerous cases are having devastating effects on wildlife species. The amphibian chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis; Bd) causes the disease chytridiomycosis that since its emergence has resulted in the extinction or serious decline of hundreds of amphibian species worldwide. In California?s Sierra Nevada, chytridiomycosis has caused the near-extinction of the once-common mountain yellow-legged frog. During summer 2012, the largest remaining mountain yellow-legged frog population will suffer a die-off event caused by the recent arrival of Bd in the area. In mountain yellow-legged frog populations the arrival of Bd in a previously uninfected population typically results in frog population extinction, and the goal of the proposed study is to change the outcome to long-term frog population persistence. This disease intervention will take the form of a field experiment implemented during the Bd-caused frog die-off. In this experiment the effectiveness of two treatments, (1) an antifungal drug, and (2) the augmentation of antifungal bacteria that occur naturally on frog skin, will be assessed at the scale of an entire frog population. This experiment will also provide an opportunity to describe the mechanisms underlying treatment effectiveness, including the role of the frog immune system, the microbial community present on the skin of frogs, and rapid evolution in frogs. Based on results from previous laboratory and small-scale field trials it is expected that antifungal drug and bacterial augmentation treatments will increase frog survival relative to frogs that are left untreated. Results from the proposed study will have important implications for conservation efforts aimed at wildlife species worldwide that are threatened by emerging diseases (e.g., amphibians, bats, apes). The study will also provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, with every effort made to include those from underrepresented groups to the maximum extent possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The amphibian chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis; "Bd") has recently spread worldwide and has caused the decline or extinction of hundreds of amphibian species, with hundreds of additional species at risk. In response to this severe impact on global amphibian biodiversity, an international research effort is currently underway to develop methods to mitigate the effects of Bd. Our collaborative project (University of California Santa Barbara, University of California Berkeley, San Francisco State University) provided an important contribution to this effort by testing in the field two methods of reducing the impact of Bd on amphibians. Our research focused on the mountain yellow-legged frog, and complex of two closely-related species (Rana muscosa, Rana sierrae) that are highly susceptible to Bd, and whose Bd-caused declines are sufficiently severe that both species were listed as "endangered" under the U.S. Endangered Species Act in 2014.

 

In the first study, we conducted a field experiment to test whether treating Bd-infected juvenile mountain yellow-legged frogs with an anti-fungal drug (to reduce their infection intensities) and augmenting anti-Bd bacteria that exist naturally on frog skin could increase frog survival during Bd outbreaks. Over the short term (3 months), treated frogs had lower Bd infection intensities and higher survival than did untreated frogs. However, the treatment failed to improve long-term survival (12 months), and the entire study population of frogs, including both treated and untreated animals, was extirpated within one year after the treatments.

 

In the second study, we used another field experiment to test whether frog susceptibility to Bd could be reduced by "immunizing" frogs against Bd. To do so, we collected Bd-naive frogs from the wild, infected them with Bd in the laboratory (in an effort to activate an immune response against Bd), and then before Bd infection reached lethal levels we cleared them of Bd using an anti-fungal drug. Frogs were then reintroduced into Bd-positive habitats in the wild, and during the subsequent year the Bd infection intensities and survival of Bd-exposed frogs was compared with that of Bd-naive frogs. This experiment is still underway and it is too early to know whether the Bd exposures did in fact serve to activate the frogs' immune systems against Bd and protect them from subsequent Bd infection. We expect that monitoring of the study populations in 2015 will provide important insights in this regard.

 

The results from our study represent a signficant advance in our understanding of how best to mitigate the effects of Bd on amphibian populations worldwide. The comparison of our results with those obtained by research groups working on other amphibian species will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the conditions under which particular mitigation strategies are likely to be most effective. More broadly, because many emerging diseases in humans have their origins in wildlife (e.g., Ebola), studies such as ours that improve our understanding of wildlife-disease dynamics and develop methods to mitigate the effects of wildlife diseases have implications for human health.
